awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating tectonics, climate, and mammal diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
The researchers seek to understand how movement of tectonic plates, which produced major mountain barriers and influenced regional climate, controlled the evolution and geographic distribution of mammals in western North America. The EarthScope Transportable Array, a network of seismic stations, has produced data that allow an unprecedented view of the Earth's structure in the western United States, providing a unique starting point from which to consider how it came to have the 3-D structure that is imaged by seismic methods. This, combined with a rich published record of structures that record changes in plate tectonics and deformation history over the past 36 Ma, allows us to estimate crustal thickness and topography throughout the western US over this important interval in mammal evolution. The researchers propose to use 3D models to understand the collapse of topography in the western US, which led to marked changes in mammal diversification that coincide with changes in the strain rates recorded in the fault movement record. The research will be accomplished through collaboration of teams that will 1) Improve dating of the sedimentary record that contains the mammalian record, as well as focused sampling of fossils from under-represented areas and time intervals, 2) produce 3D models for lithosphere modification that account for changes in heat flux and boundary conditions, 3) model regional climate that builds on topographic constraints, 4) analyze mammal speciation and diversification and its links over time with topography and climatic gradients, and 5) synthesize all of the results into a 4D model for change through the past 36 Ma. The ultimate goal is to produce a more fundamental understanding of the factors responsible for crustal and topographic changes and how these influence mammal speciation and diversification. The quantitative analysis of crust and mantle dynamics provides an important framework for advancing knowledge in fields linked to the economic geology (mineral belts) of the southwestern US. The research will provide valuable technical training to high school, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral researchers. The collaborative team will develop several outreach products, including an informational video for the general public, materials for museum presentations and exhibits at the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History, the departmental Museum Display at Stony Brook, and materials for talks and presentations to the public.

The integrated topography model shows a Nevadaplano of ~4.36 +/- 0.4 km (1-sigma) average elevation in central, eastern, and southern Nevada, western Utah, parts of easternmost California, and central portions of westernmost Arizona at 36 Ma. Our model shows that highlands of the Nevadaplano connected to a continuous mountain chain through southeastern Arizona and into northern Mexico. This topography results from the long history of crustal shortening from Sevier - Laramide orogenies. The topography of this massive range collapsed from 36 Ma to the present, leading to as much as 200% extension, the present-day Basin and Range, and exhumation of metamorphic core complexes along the belt of thickened crust. Distributions of lithospheric body forces continue to drive this collapse today. Differences in gravitational potential energy are known to drive extensional deformation, particularly in regions of extreme topography. Yet the reasons for the timing of the collapse, along with the magnitudes and distributions of deviatoric stresses responsible for the collapse, remain enigmatic. The changing topography associated with extensional collapse dramatically altered the climate and mammal diversity dynamics of the western Cordillera. Our research targets three topics within the Integrated Earth System: (1) The topography, distribution, and 3-D deviatoric stresses responsible for the collapse history, (2) The climatic response to the collapse and generation of climate gradients, and (3) The response of mammal lineages and faunas to changing topographic and climate gradients and removal of topographic barriers. No previous study of climate gradients and their impact on mammal diversity has ever been integrated with quantitative kinematic and dynamic reconstructions of continental deformation. The intellectual merit of this study involves the power of combining these fields, while incorporating formal uncertainties in models at all stages of analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Title: Collaborative Research: Integrating Tectonics, Climate, and Mammal Diversity

Understanding the interplay between tectonics, climate, and biodiversity is essential to reconstructing Earth’s dynamic history and its influence on life. This project has provided groundbreaking insights into how the evolution of landscapes in western North America over the past 36 million years has shaped regional geology and mammalian biodiversity. Our findings integrate geophysical modeling, climate analysis, and fossil records to quantify these relationships in unprecedented detail.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit

Geodynamic Evolution of the Western United States

The transition from a subduction-dominated to a transform-dominated margin since 36 million years ago resulted in dramatic topographic collapse and widespread extension. Geophysical modeling revealed that at 36 million years ago, the Nevadaplano—a highland region—stood at an average elevation of nearly 4 km before collapsing into the present-day Basin and Range Province. This collapse was primarily driven by lithospheric body forces and changes in plate boundary conditions rather than mantle convection alone.

Formation of Metamorphic Core Complexes

Extreme crustal extension exposed deep metamorphic rocks at the surface, forming metamorphic core complexes. Our models demonstrate that these complexes are the result of gravitational body forces acting on thickened crust, leading to ductile flow and detachment faulting. These features are fossil signatures of ancient highland collapse and provide new perspectives on crustal deformation processes in extensional tectonic settings.

Landscape Evolution and Drainage Reorganization

The collapse of highlands in southwestern North America reshaped regional drainage patterns. Early rivers drained northeastward onto the Colorado Plateau before reversing to a southwestward direction in the late Oligocene. These drainage shifts correspond to changes in tectonic stress regimes and topographic evolution, emphasizing the deep connection between tectonics and surface processes.

Tectonic Controls on Mammalian Diversity

Tectonic activity has had a profound influence on the biodiversity of the Basin and Range Province. By integrating fossil records with geophysical models, we show that mammalian species richness and turnover closely track changes in topography and extensional strain rates. Peaks in diversity coincide with periods of rapid landscape change, suggesting that tectonic processes create environmental gradients that drive speciation.

Role of Sediment Accumulation in the Fossil Record

While tectonically driven sediment deposition influences the preservation of fossils, our research reveals that the Miocene peak in mammalian diversity was not merely an artifact of increased fossil burial. Instead, it reflects actual biodiversity increases driven by complex topography, which created diverse ecological niches. 

Broader Impacts

This research has had a significant impact on workforce development and education by training the next generation of geoscientists. It has directly supported the training of three Ph.D. students, multiple undergraduate researchers, and high school students through hands-on research experiences in geodynamic modeling, structural geology, and geochemistry. By integrating these students into cutting-edge research, the project has fostered critical thinking, technical skills, and interdisciplinary collaboration—key attributes for careers in academia, industry, and government.

The project has also contributed to broader STEM education by incorporating research findings into university curricula and outreach programs. Teaching materials, including case studies and datasets developed from this work, have been used in undergraduate and graduate courses, enhancing scientific literacy and inquiry-based learning. Additionally, engagement with educators through workshops and presentations has helped integrate modern geoscience concepts into K-12 education.

Beyond academia, the study has societal implications for understanding geologic hazards, resource management, and environmental change. By improving knowledge of the geodynamic evolution of the Southwest Cordillera, the research informs strategies for managing water resources, mineral exploration, and seismic hazards. The findings are also relevant for geothermal energy and critical mineral exploration.

Finally, this project has strengthened research infrastructure by advancing computational modeling capabilities and fostering collaborations across multiple institutions. The development of accessible geophysical and geochemical datasets ensures that these findings remain valuable to the broader scientific and public communities, supporting future innovation in Earth sciences.
